description: Diaphanous is a classic Hueco testpiece climbing out a steep ironrock wall on incut crimps. Start on an obvious low incut and make a few moves to a dyno and a good flake. Finish up the V5 above.

name: Mexican Love Handle
description: fun sloping pinches

name: Girls of Juarez
description: Start on an adjacent rock on a huge flake.  This rock is considered on for both hands and feet.  From the flake work your way out underneath the capstone on mostly good holds utilizing toe and heel hooks.  As you approach the end of the capstone grab good holds over the lip and pull up onto the boulder.

name: Gums
description: Crux is at the bottom, technical climbing on small holds.

name: Power of Silence
description: This Fred Nicole test piece will offer up a challenge for anyone climbing the grade.  Stack pads or get a lift and start matched on the lowest good crimp. For most people the crux is sticking the decent pocket out right. This move requires tension and accuracy while using a left hand crimp and worse-than-it-looks right foot. A desperate stab into the fingerlock guards the last reach to the lip before topping out.  Classic and hard, Power of Silence shouldn't be missed on your trip to Hueco Tanks.

name: The Melon Patch
description: Crux is at the bottom, then you follow jugs up the gently overhanging face.

name: Loaded With Power
description: A beautiful, almost uncanny Hueco feature. Stand start left side in big undercling. Go up and right through a sharp, but incut crimp.

name: Ghetto Simulator
description: A very, very long climb with a cruxy finish. Amazing line though, everyone should do this climb when visiting Hueco! This is a very long climb, but not too tall because an angling ramp follows you the whole way up.

name: To Die For
description: This line climbs a series of slopey jug huecos to a commiting gaston move and cross over high off the deck.  An amazing find only done (I'm guessing) in 2008.

name: Lip Sync
description: Fun climbing on incut jugs. The start is the crux, start on the very right side of the boulder and follow the jugs left working upwards to a good lip. Once you hit the dish, mantle the lip and climb straight up to top out.

name: Shamu
description: Start Free Willy, but continue up through thin holds to a less victorious final crux. This less contrived, more direct variation of Free Willy utilizes the thin left hand crimp you normally dyno from as a right hand instead. It is an excellent problem in it's own right, and for those who can't pull the dyno of FW, a good consolation prize.

name: Dean's Journey
description: The crux is releasing the left hand from the sloper to lean out to the good sloping rail, matching it, and holding the swing.      One of the most unique boulder problems in Hueco Tanks if not the world, Dean's Journey is a unique experience full of fun thuggy moves bizarre mantles and improbable holds.

name: Free willy
description: Note: My understanding is that the holds to the left (on the Pussy Route) are off limits for Free Willy.     Start with a good right hand in the low pockets and a left sloping crimp. You can start with a right heel hook by your right hand and a left back step (traditional beta), or just toe down on some bad feet. Go left hand to the sloper, right hand to the tooth and continue up and eventually right on pretty decent crimps. The finish can be done one of two ways: go left hand to the bad crimp, hike a high right foot and dyno to the lip with your right hand, or you can use the bad 1/4" sloping crimp with your right as an intermediate before going to the lip. Not really sure which one is easier, but I felt the intermediate was more consistent.

name: The Dripping Gash
description: Good landing, gets thin up high, but it's all there. Fun slab problem!

name: Orifice Affair
description: Sit start and climb the line of hueco's.  Beware some aren't quite as good as they look.

name: Roughage
description: **Effective December 2014 this climb is closed**    This stellar problem doesn't have any super difficult moves, but every move is solid with a consistent difficulty until the top.   Begin on a good left facing sidepull and climb left through a decent pinch to a small undercling.  From here make a big move to a good crimp, match and make a committing move to a jug.  This gives a chance for a shake as while from here things ease up, it will keep you on your toes until the top.    Probably on the easier side of V7, but the excitement of a possible fall makes up for it.

name: Smooth Move
description: Start on any part of the huge undercling hueco, likely with left foot low and right in the bottom of the hueco. Go big, slam dunk. Match, trend a bit right and then up.

name: The Wonder Dyno
description: This is the obvious sit start to Wonderhole. Sit start matched on the rail down and right of the hole, with one heck of a greasy foot. Make one huge throw to the large hueco and top out.

name: Unknown
description: This stellar problems ascends the bullet iron rock face.  While fairly tall there is a large slab behind you can step off onto if you get flustered.  The first move is probably the hardest but it doesn't get that much easier.  Everything is solid but use care on the topout.

name: Guns of Navarone
description: This savage crimp line would be four stars if only the holds weren't quite so sharp!    Begin sitting on your choice of two of three heavily chalked crimps.  Make a hard move, possibly the crux, up to better holds.  From here work your way left through several holds and eventually a long reach.  Top out on good but potentially very chossy holds.  Beware the huge flake on the right of the topout as it is very hollow sounding.

name: The Laughing Sutra
description: Start stemming up the alcove heading for the see-thru hueco. From here, go right for the top out.

name: Denizen
description: Low start matched with right hand on undercling left hand on the slopey top. Follow the arête eventually pulling a long move left to the side pull jugs on the face pull a long move to the right hand jug then hit the hidden jug up top then pull the easy top out.  Fantastic arête climb with long powerful moves.

name: Groupie Alert
description: Located on the South Groupie Alert boulder. Start on the left side of the face, 5ft. left of the tan streak, at a good hueco. Climb straight up through long pulls to a committing and highly satisfying finish.

name: TNT
description: Start on the left facing jug. Slap right, around the bulge, and do a rising traverse following good huecos, maybe enjoy the sweet cross match undercling midway. Keep cruising, and top out!  Started messing with this with Phillip Sweeney, while Mike and the gang were crushing Bloodline. The holds were sandy and chalkless. I assumed my send was the FA, while Mike M. got the second in flip flops, and called it, "classic Hueco V2".

name: Bloodline
description: An atypical hueco rock climb. Great movement that requires balance and technique. There's a left start and a direct start that's a little more difficult.

name: El Techo de los Tres B
description: Rad, roof starting deep in the cave on an obvious jug.

name: shaved pits
description: start in lowest hueco, go left a bit, and go big to the jug

name: NE Face
description: The north face of the north deliverance boulder ranges from V0 to V1. Climbing directly up to the peak is a great clean line that goes at about V1, and is thinnest about 3/4 of the way up.

name: East face
description: thin slab on pretty dark rock, fairly committing top out

name: Witness the Slickness
description: Start with low, wide sidepulls.  Gain slopers and follow them to finish with jugs.

name: Unknown wall 2
description: Start in a horizontal that is a bit on the low side and work up fun hueco seams that yield jugs. Leading to a thin move about 10 feet up. Another long move leads to the angling crack high on the face and an easier top out.    The landing has 2 tiers so padding both and having a good spot would be a good idea if you think you might come off.

name: Stinkfoot
description: Tall slabby fun

name: Unknown wall 1
description: Start kind of low, you could probably sit. Climb up on nice hueco flakes that are mostly side pulls until you reach the angling crack across the top of the face. From here things get easier to the top.

name: Slayride
description: Good rock, nice holds, engaging top out are all good things. The hardest move right off the ground would normally be bad but with the poor landing is probably a plus as well.    Start on some small holds and explode up to a flat jug. float the jugs up and left to a hueco. Then head up past a spooky looking block to a sloping lip encounter.

name: Jigsaw Puzzle
description: One of the best V5s, this problem starts at the right side of a face that resembles a jigsaw puzzle.  Climb the boulder from left to right trending upwards and toping out on the right side of the boulder.

name: Jingus Bells
description: Crux is the last move of this climb.  Maybe better rated as 5.12 a/b.  Begin down and left of the obvious chalked ending.  Weave your way through varried and fun moves to the end.  The dyno is SICK.  Don't be afraid to go for it as you land safe and sound onto the boulder behind every time.  Nice to have a chalkbag on this one.

name: Slim Pickins
description: Scary highball slab up and to the right of Jigsaw Puzzle.  You have to be a slab master for this one!

name: Javalina
description: Sweet traverse on jugs, would be worthy of 4 stars if dabbing halfway through was not an issue.    Head right from the low jugs near the middle of the wall.start out traversing more or less along the lip at one point using a hold under the lip. Eventually move up into a good left hand sidepull half pocket and make a long reach out right to an undercling, match your left foot to hand as either a toe or heal toe and drop your left down to a good seem. Now for the anti dab first crux, release the foot and swing onto the hand holds with a smear for your right foot. The rest of the problem is tough enduro climbing, big moves on bigish holds. Bump your left further along the seam and make a long move out right to the left end of another seam with a flat hold that sort of tilts toward you. Get a right heal hook and match up to make another long move right to a better hold. Some consider this the end of the problem but for full credit top it out, the climbing is easier but not neseccarily a gimmie, I've seen someone pitch from above here.

name: Better Eat Your Wheaties
description: A classic crimp problem, Because of the nature of the holds this problem really is not all that height dependant.    From the start side pull get your feet on, either a good right or both, or a high left depending on your preference. If you are small bury the left hand side pull, if big, crush it for all your worth. Reach or bump your way up to a sharp edge that is some what of a gaston. Move your feet around and reach the pinch right at the lip. From here there are several ways to finish, and the next move or two are the crux. However you do it you will be tic-tacing your way up some pretty small holds that are on a vertical wall while your feet are still on the overhang.      To top out move left in the horizontal below the next over hanging panel and up at a flake at mid-height on this next overhanging panel. This is easier that the rest of the problem but it never hurts to have a look in advance just to see where those top out holds are over the lip.   Location   From the meadow between the Maze and East Mt head throught the tunnel formed by the big boulder that is furthest to the left and the short wall to the right, when you get through you will be looking at an overhung wall that has lots of chalk and features. This one starts high on a good left-hand sidepull and right-hand crimper/gaston, in the middle/right of the face where there is another rock behind the steep face.

name: Crown of Aragorn
description: Starts in a scoop on the arete to the right of Better Eat Your Wheaties and traverses left on impossibly small crimps to finish on Wheaties.

name: The Vulgarian
description: Big holds up an overhang.  How can you go wrong?  Right as you walk into The Gunks this is the first climb past The Full Monty on the same side. Starts in the middle of the face and goes slightly left.      If you're not on jugs you are off route.

name: Fight or Flight
description: Start on a high left facing hueco and move upward through sequential moves on flakes that get increasingly worse as you go.  Match the top flake and make a heady move to the top of the boulder.  Match and pull over to the finish.  The book lists this as a challenging mantel, but with the right holds it shouldn't feel too bad.  Might be a good idea to pre-inspect the topout if you are at your limit.    There is also a sit start to this that adds in a few moves and bumps the grade up to V6.

name: The Hunger Artist aka Alf in a Blender
description: An amazing classic.  Start on a two hand undercling under the roof.  Slap out the sloping left hand rail, apply some foot trickery and make you way onto better holds.  Many ways to approach this one.  Once you piece it together it seems easier.

name: The Cornerstone AKA: Dean's Corner
description: Very striking line up the steep corner with a finger crack to a moderately difficult but quite high top out onto a slab. The only real line on the wall.    Get your right hand as high in the corner as you can and stand up. Arrange your feet into some sort of a wide stem and pull up as high as you can. There is a sloping edge a bit below where the crack actually opens up that you can pause on to readjust your feet or just bump off of. Claw for where the crack opens. Then get your feet up and match. Layback up the corner eventually with good feet out right till you get to the lip. Reach up to the lip and grab some good slopers and pull over to the right or more straight up.    Graded V4 in the guide book. It might be V4 if you are well over 6 feet tall or you somehow don't take into account the first moves.

name: New Religion
description: A gym climbers dream.  Steep, positive holds, long moves, mellow topout.  A sit start exists that goes at V8.  If you don't have fun on this one something is wrong.

name: Bush League
description: Start on jugs to the left in the roof, a couple of moves head right to a threader jug. A big move out right to the arete starts the business, cool compression follows the steep arete to good holds at the lip.    This problem would be pretty amazing if it was 3-5 feet higher off the ground, though dabbing was not really an issue.    Originally graded V10, the grade seems to have settled at V8.     There might be a knee bar somewhere but I did not see anything that would be useful, though I suck at knee barring.

name: Bad Religion
description: Stand start from the left large hueco and traverse to the right into New Religion.

name: The Handcuff Trick
description: Tall and aesthetic layback slab crack. Must do!

name: Purple Flowers (Les Fleurs Pourpes)
description: This problem begins way back in the cave scrunched up on a rock on two underclings.  Work your way around the roof to (hopefully) a kneebar and then kick over to the slab (another boulder) and finish on that boulder.  There is so much beta and so many different ways of doing this climb that I'm not going to include the beta for this one although I will say that there are up to 3 kneebars and the best beta deviates from Fred Nicole's original version that he graded V10 (and is still reflected in the Wilder book).

name: Glas Roof
description: From underclings got right to a nice long pocket that you can pinch at the bottom, then match with the left pinchig the top in a sort of back handed grip (with your palm facing you). Get a right drop knee and hit the crimpy pinch at the lip. Get a bicycle with your feet and bump your left hand out into another pocket. Then learn to foot jam and stuff your right foot in the pocket that you just matched. Reach up left to the 2 finger on the face and get a left heal scum. Right hand up to a small but good edge. Now for the crux, do something with your feet to help you throw your body up and left to a very good edge. From this edge climb up a move or two and back down to drop off.    If you want to try and top out...well I'm not sure it is a good idea.

name: The Egg
description: Great sloper problem. Graded V10 when first put up, I feel that the V8 grade from the guide book is a bit of a sandbag though V10 might be a bit generous.    Start in a left kneebar with some bad underclings, it might be possible to pull on without the kneebar, but it would be heinous. Reach out to a sharp jug over the lip and match. Your kneebar should kind of pop out easily considering how hard it is to get in in the first place, get a right toe hook. Reach left to some slopers and move your right foot to a heal on the jug and squeeze your left foot into the underclings. Mess around on the slopers untill you have a left false grip on the furthest left lump and ring your heal into the furthest right sloper. Move your right hand up into a crimpy undercling and smear your left foot on something just over the lip of the roof that looks as though you will not stick to it and hit the sloping rail up and left as a gaston. Bump your hand up untill you get to a good spot. Swing your left foot back under the roof to get a toe hook that is bad which allows you to match the sloping rail and push up and left to a jug at the top.    You can literaly slip off of just about any move on this problem which makes it pretty cool, you have to use your whole body to stay on the rock.

name: Flower Power
description: If you are strong enough this could be an easy tick or still impossible. It all depends on how the flying ninja kick at the end goes for you, easy for some, impossible for others, though there is alternate beta which makes the problem longer.    Start on a big tounge at the right end of the roof. Work your way left on sequency pockets untill you make a slap for a sloping bump on a vertical section of rock. Get a right toe hook to bump your right hand into a closer pocket. Then walk your feet through to a heal hook just below your left hand and pull up onto an alcove with an 8 finger fin that sticks down as an undercling. Walk your feet into the alcove in a kind of stem and match hands to go out left and out the roof to a better hold the a good right in opposition. Next reach up right into a scoop to a honeycomb crimp with a thumb catch then left to a fin that is a side pull/undercling. Get a big drop knee and make a long pull to a hueco, as you work further around the side it gets better. Now for the fun bit, cut your feet but don't try to check the swing, instead kick out for the boulder behind and to the right of you. Get your feet to stick, match the hueco and shoulder your way over to the vertical face and top out.

name: That Hi-Pro Glow
description: Start matched on a big sloper.  Figure out how to move right through good holds to reach jugs in the crack.  From here climb leftwards on good holds to the finish, climbing under a few branches.    Very aesthetic route with great movement.  Probably on the easier side of V6.

name: Mr Serious
description: From the start make a move into a good sidepull then a hard move into the perfectly circular pocket. Figure out how to move your feet up and pull off of the pocket to get to something terrible and either use it or turn the pocket and go again. A few easier moves up on better holds takes one to the top of the boulder.   There is a lower sit/laydown start down to the right that makes this problem V10 and is called Dead Serious

name: The French Tickler
description: This route is the obvious line in the center of Stable Rock.  Begins on the large sloping jugs at head height and climbs straight up through small crimps and sloping gastons to a committing lunge at the finish.      Beta:  Begin on the sloping jugs and take the first 1/2 pad crimp with your right hand.  Heel up on the sloping jugs and reach up left hand to a good but slightly sharp gaston.  Stand up and get a horrid right hand crimp, then back step the 1/2 pad crimp with your right foot and lunge for a decent crimp out and right from your right hand (crux).  Left foot goes on a good smear onto up your left hand (coolest move ever) and lock off to the first gaston sloper.  Move your feet out left to get the second right hand gaston sloper.  Left foot up to the decent crimp and lunge for the sloping jug at the top out.  Mega-classic.  My favorite line in Hueco.

name: Smokin Sausage
description: awkward hard start, starts left hand in a hueco right on a crimp to fun easy climbing.

name: The Long Haul
description: This route begins on a jug under the roof that is on your left as you enter the center of the Sausage Factory.  Climbs out tension slopers and jugs to a big move to a gaston and a bump that will get you to the lip.    3 stars for cool holds, movement, and obvious line. -1 for the leg breaking boulder to your left as you do the committing moves to the lip.

name: Ministry of Truth
description: Pretty pure power problem and not too tweaky.    From a high two hand edge campus up to another edge. Then figure out how to get to the crack above, there are a couple of different ways to do it. The crack above is easy and you will have the edges as feet to start.

name: The  Bacchanalian (AKA Balls of Steele)
description: Start with a kneebar as for "The Bomb," but head up and left above the blocky landing zone.  The crux is up high, but it is mostly a power endurance problem.  This problem is not in the current guide (Wilder, 1st edition) and is well worth seeking out if you are looking for something off the beaten path.

name: Fluffy's Revenge
description: On the right side of the wall, start the same as for Fluff Cycle on the low block, then go up and rightward on some small holds. The feet are limited, so some inverted beta may be needed.

name: Fluff Cycle
description: On the right side of the wall, sit start on a crimpy block, then up to a sharp undercling feature. Climb left until the undercling ends and then do something creative to get to the jugs at the lip.

name: Frogger
description: Start low at 3 ft. using foot rail to the right. Climb up and left on sharp crimps to the highest point on the face.

name: Satan, Satan, Satan
description: Really fun line of huecos on the far right side of the wall with Rembrandt Pussyhorse. Start as low as you can in the huecos and go straight up. The topout is the crux.

name: Sweat Loaf
description: Sit start in the middle of the Sweat Loaf boulder. Follow the fun huecos up, and make a big move left for the classic finish. Topout is probably easier than Satan, Satan, Satan.

name: The Ostracizer
description: Starts on a huge flake with the crux being the toss to the left after the flake ends.

name: Tri Hard
description: The stand start to Try Harder. Big moves on sloping huecos above a huge undercut roof.

name: Dragon Fly, AKA: Dogmatics
description: Once and still considered a mega-classic. Follow the left angling flake crack with good holds that are quite spaced and bad feet to its end on a monster jug. Make a huge move out left to an OK hold, heal hook right and go right hand to a gaston. Then swing the feet left to another heal and go to a left hand gaston, step up and top out.    Alternately, go the the right hand gaston with the left hand as a side pull and make a big move straight up the blunt prow over a worse landing for a slightly harder and more direct finish. Seems to be rarely done, but it is actually quite good especially if you've done the original finish multiple times.   Location   Just left of Dry Dock around the corner following the sweet left arching flake/crack.

name: Hobbit in a Blender
description: A great problem with a tough opening move and a comitting move up higher to a cool mantle. The start holds are reputedly chipped out to be better, though there is so much chalk on them now that it is hard to tell though it seems plausible.    Start on the two positive crimps and get one foot or the other on and bust a move out right to gaston at the bottom of the crack. Get a foot up near the start holds and fall in to match in the crack. Layback up a move or two and make a long move up to a jug at the top of the crack. You can top out straight up but it is better to do another long move out right to another jug and hand foot match on the first and mantle from here up to some edges on the face above.

name: Ides of March
description: The rightmost problem of the 3 on this face of the boulder.  Make sure you have a good spotter because of the boulder behind you.

name: Hector in a Blender
description: This problem named in honor of the park ranger Hector, starts in Ides of March and ends to the left on Brutus. Hector always said he climbed and he understood climbers and what we were about, nice generalization since all climbers are definitly the same. Sometimes it's an honor to be put in a blender and sometimes not, Hobbit, Brittney, Alf etc. we'll leave this open to interpretation.    From the start of Ides of March make thin, long moves up and left into the middle of Brutus. The holds are particularly thin and sharp but is worth doing if you've already done Ides and Brutus.

name: Dry Dock
description: Crux is either the first move or the top out if you are figuring it out on the fly.  Many believe this hard for the grade.  This problem is SICK!!!!!

name: Brittany in a Blender
description: A very pretty problem, with unique holds and puzzling movement.    Sit start on an obvious slopey shelf and go straight up using edges, underclings, a very slopey pod, and some kneebar trickery until you reach two very small, sharp crimps on the lip of the roof.  Mantle up and left over a slightly scary slab.  Hence the PG13.

name: Try Harder
description: This problem begins under the roof matched on an undercling.  Climbs through some compression moves until a toss into a pocket (inside a hueco).  4 stars for awesome holds, movement, landing and obvious line.      Beta:  Start  matched on the undercling and squeeze between two opposing feet.  Through out right hand to an undercling and toss again for a 90 degree angled sloper.  Right foot over to compress on a heel hook down and right of your hand.  Bump left hand into a bad pinch eight inches from the starting hold and switch your left foot from a heel hook on the starting hold to a good toe hook.  Sag.  Match the other 90 degree hold right next to your left hand.  Switch the right heel hook to pushing with your toe and do a dynamic move to the lip, you will begin to cut feet and swing out desperately so very quickly swing your right hand to an undercling a foot (back) into the cave.  Heel hook up and match the large hueco.  (This is the beginning of Try Hard FA Ricky O V5).  Cross into an undercling pinch at the top of the hueco and left hand to a decent crimp.  Switch you heel to a toe and surge up to a good but hard to hold hueco.  Match your right foot to your left and toe hook the right undercling by your hand, reach up (slowly... slowly...) to a jug on the lip rock over.

name: Full Service
description: This is the original V10 at Hueco (the standard for V10, in fact), and it is still considered by many to be the best. It was one of the most sought after ticks in the '90's and it still is for that matter.  John Sherman originally envisioned the line and had done the stand, Lip Service, when Dale Goddard sent the full rig, calling it "Serves You Right." However, Sherman's name, "Full Service," seems to have stuck.

name: Mojo
description: Start on the "trailer hitch" hold and a foot out right power through hard to hold pinches and slap your way to the angled jug.  Most people drop off from here, but for full value do the top out.  The feet are choss, but as long as your track hands and feet you'll be fine.  3 stars for awesome holds, powerful movement and a fine landing.  -1 stars for being a drop off or for the chossy highball top out.

name: Fearless Driving Rain
description: A tall V6 with excellent moves on excellent rock.  The crux is low, but the top keeps you paying attention.

name: Wicked Twisted Road
description: Start at the back of the low roof, climb out and onto very left side of the tall slab.  Downclimb the slab 10 feet to the right.

name: Sex After Death
description: Claimed to have been chipped, but I don't see it. In the Sherman guide books the ledge to the left is listed as off and pretty easy to avoid, if you are tall and it is on the problem is significantly easier, the newer Wilder book makes no mention of the ledge one way or another.    From the 3 finger pocket to start move up left to a tooth and crush to move right to a sloping 3 finger dish. Either jump or get a high drop knee to move up left to a sloping edge. Next out right to a sidepull and cross through to another sidepull. A long reach up to an angling crack that is good and is followed to the top.

name: Moonshine Roof (center)
description: Starting pockets rumored to have been chipped out, there is an alternate start that is no harder that does a couple of moves straight in line with the diving board if you need to have an unaltered ascent.    Start on a sloping boulder with hands in the two pockets, pull on and make a big move out the roof to a jug, make sure to keep the landing gear up or you will surely be dragging body parts across the boulder that you started on. Mount the diving board and work out left on the dual rails. At the end of the rails make big crux moves on slopers with heal and toe hooks on the diving board up into a higher section of roof. Eventually gain a jug under the lip, facing right reach over the lip to a hold and work up on holds that could be better.

name: Moonshine Right
description: This fun climb was once a gimme for the grade, now that a large jug at the lip has broken off it may feel difficult for V5.    Start in the same pockets as "Moonshine Roof" climb out to the surfboard and continue straight.  Make a tricky move to get into the undercling and bump out to the lip.  Figure out how to keep the feet on to match the lip, and pull the tricky rock over onto the face.

name: Moonshine Left
description: This less popular Moonshine route is just as classic as the others imo.  Be prepared for a stout grade and quite a pump for a boulder problem.  Start in the shared pockets with the V4 "Moonshine Roof", and climb onto the diving board.  Where "Moonshine Roof" breaks right continue straight and around the corner thru challenging beta intensive moves.  Get established under the final roof with a good left hand and enter the crux pulling over the final lip to good holds above.  Some toe hook trickey can help to get matched on the final holds before the move to the jugs leading to the topout.

name: Power of Landjager
description: Start low in the dihedral. Move out on jugs to a left hand crimp. Heel hook or dyno to the sloping jug and start hold of Sound of Power. Finish on that climb.

name: Meddle Detector
description: Start off with a big move/dyno to a comfortable jug out in the roof. Continue out on nice flake jugs untill you arrive at a couple of nice underclings. Get a knee scum to make a big move up to a sharp small crimp. Figure out how to use this to move left to another good hold at the bottom right of a huge depression, some foot trickery is required. Then traverse left along the base of the depression into teh corner which is followed to the top. Once you reach the corner the problem is pretty much over, you would have to try to fall off if you made it this far.   This is one of the best V6's anywhere. Fun movement, a good variety of hold types and moves. Long enough to not just be over. High enough to be somewhat commiting.

name: Conservative Backlash
description: Spectacular balancy arete climb! Maybe one of the best V0s in the park if flat landings are a criteria for you.

name: The Banzai Knife
description: A hard start on crimps takes you up the initial face to where you can move left into the flake and over the higher landing platform. Follow the flake as it angles up and left above the higher landing area. At the end of the flake pull up to the sloping lip and make tough and intimidating moves onto the slab above.    The top out on this problem is not your typical Hueco Tanks finish, no jugs up there.

name: Snakecharmer
description: One of the best problems of the grade in the park.    Start on the right facing 3 finger jug at the base of the arete. Move up through the bulge to double pinches. Figure out some sneaky feet to get up to the next pair of holds, a slopy pinch and a good edge. Set your feet and make a scary move to the angling lip feature. Follow the lip up and right to top out where you can squeeze past the wall behind.

name: Hobbit with a Boner
description: Great roof climb with seemingly horrific, but manageable start and finish "landings". Manageable, as in, it can be protected with good padding and spotters; but really, one should be confident in climbing in this grade range before giving this serious attempts IMHO.

name: Low Dryer
description: Start in slopey undercling down low and hug your way up to Blow Dryer.  Don't know how the first ascentionist did the cruxy first move, but a proper sit-start definitely makes a difference compared to crouching, albeit not a grade harder imo.

name: Dark Angel
description: Climb the crack in a corner. You can jam straight in, layback or stem. The crack is almost all hand sized for those with average sized mitts.

name: Backdoor Man
description: Start on the high right facing flake and climb up on great holds to the top.  The first moves are the hardest, but the top gets quite high.

name: Swirl Wall
description: Standing start from the lower left on a small rail. Traverse right and up on decent holds to a cool, balancy mantle to a crimp. Make another move or two to the rollover lip and some friable holds. Use a bit of caution topping out. Walk off left.

name: Jiffy Pop
description: Weird press/mantle thingy to a seam and chossy top out or chimney.    Start from a jug rail and move up and left on a sloper. Figure out how to get up to the seam 8 feet above you. Once in the seam work up that to the top. At this point you will be below a cap stone and the holds moving right out from under it are choss, however the opposite wall of the corridor is right behind you. What you do is up to you.

name: Ventral Fin
description: Sit start on a sloper and crimp. Climb the overhanging arete and face.

name: Tall Cool Red One
description: An amazing highball with a good landing.    Start out by moving up past the right edge of the large scoop feature. Then head left across the scoop aiming for the sloping ramp that leads up to a white jug, crux. From the jug a huge move gains the obvious flake and another big move to the lip. Beware of loose rock over the lip when topping out.

name: Jamocha Joe aka Purple Bunny Fuckers
description: Start on the great left facing flake under the large roof.  Make a large move out to a good hold and try to keep your feet on the wall, or cut them and keep them off the ground.  From here turn left and make a big move to a slopy pocket.  Get a good undercling, and cross into a horizontal seam.  Work this slightly left and make a big throw to a huge jug.  Match here and drop off or continue up the chossy squeeze chimney and walk around through on the kitty litter ledge.    Name and Grade are both guesses as this is a fairly new problem, and I couldn't find it on Nick's scorecard.

name: Ultramega
description: This problem beings low (no lower) on the "holster" pocket and another jug.  Start crossed and move through the jugs until you get to an undercling.  Reach out left to an ok pocket and bicycle.  THe crux is the next two moves establishing on the next thin finger lock pocket and then reaching up to a crimp work your feet to a good foot out left and reach a juggy pocket.  Cross left hand to the next crimp then cross back underneath your left hand to an undercling jug.  Slap up to the lip and bump until you can get a left heel hook on the lip and (red point crux) surge out to a good right hand crimp.  Rock over.  3 stars for awesome holds, movement and obvious line, -1 star for the slab at your back which is annoying more than anything.

name: Something Different
description: Start on juggy crimps and follow a set of crimps til a throw move out left.  Match and punch to the arete again for the delicate top out.  4 stars for excellent holds, movement, obvious line and landing.

name: Taxing the Pipe
description: Arete and compression climbing on perfect rock.  More about finesse than power.    Start on double underclings and lunge to a sloper.  Bump your left hand up the arete and make a hard move to a sidepull on the face.  Shuffle up the arete some more, go to another sidepull.  Move your feet out right, cross over to a sloper, match, and fire for the lip.    The last 3 moves are the hardest.  Would get 4 stars if it wasn't so close to other boulders.    The PG13 comes from the eerily close wall behind you when you toss for the top.  No one ever hit it, but it feels like you could.

name: Rose Fruited Juniper
description: Start on the great left facing flake under the large roof. Make a large move out to a good hold and try to keep your feet on the wall, or cut them and keep them off the ground. From here throw left hand to a slopy pocket and work the core tension to bring your right hand up to a good crimp.  From here traverse straight right crossing your left hand into a good pocket.  Now figure out how to obtain and match the miserable crimp directly right.   Once matched move right to a good sidepull and stand up to an undercling.  Finish up the easy slab.    Originally rated V11 but if I could do it then it's not V11, so grade is my guess.    Named after the Large Juniper that's in the area.  That Juniper tree is the oldest living thing in the park.

name: Anything but Dull
description: Climb up great rock on huecos and rounded holds with some pretty long reaches. Committing moves through the middle portion of the problem. Might be dusty due to lack of traffic.

name: The Fin
description: The venerable classic, and the main reason to drop your pads at the Aircraft Carrier.   Start on the head-height jug moving into the arete with a couple positive holds, then a sloping side-pull.  Use your arete skills to gain balance for the lip, or just move into it with some swing.  Finish slightly left.

name: Winged Victory
description: Start on good holds and figure out how to get to the next set of jugs.  Most campus but there is some toe hook beta as well.  Once the next set of jugs have been obtained head up on easier moves to one more tricky move to get established on the face.  Keep it together for the high topout and beware of any Hueco choss.

name: Unlock This AKA:The Locksmith sit-start
description: The sucktastic climb that is Locksmith is completely redeemed with the low start in the big hueco.  Undercling to the crimp and toe-hook to acquire a right hand.  Here's where it gets tricky as the toe release can send you off.  Figure out the balance then throw to the start hold of Locksmith while keeping your feet off the pads.  Finish out on Locksmith.      This appears to be a newer route but has excellent movement rivaling the classic of the area.

name: Snakebelly
description: Sit start on the obvious jugs about 10 feet further in the cave, and then finish The Fin.

name: Double Pecan
description: Start underclings and find cryptic sequence through roof to gain the lip. Trend right and up. The Wilder guide doesn't give this climb much love, but it has great movement. The Wilder guide also gives this climb a V9, but once the beta is unlocked, this problem is more in the ball park of a solid V7 or soft V8.

name: Mr. Freud
description: Neglected problem near s-curve area. Start on a high flake in the center of the scoop and climb straight up. Downclimb is to the right, you will find a flake to scramble down.

name: Wutang
description: Start on the big undercling under the roof. Make a big move out to a crimp and climb steep crimps to a slightly chossy but juggy topout.

name: A.K.A.
description: Sit start on the far right side of the roof, almost outside of the cave. Move up and left across the roof to gain the left arete.  The crux is turning the lip after 35' of roof climbing.  Top out with a 20' V1 slab.

name: El Burro
description: Start low on opposing sidepulls.  Make challenging moves on slopey pockets to another tricky move towards the top.  From here things ease off for the topout.  The Wilder guide mentions that this is "A challenge for any V3 climber - V10 climber for that matter."  It held up to it's reputation as I found it just as challenging as the harder lines on the wall.

name: Left Donkey Show
description: This classic line may be easy if you have enough reach, or extremely challenging if you can't reach the horizontal rail.  Start on a sidepull and jug at 6 ft, make a move into an undercling and make a big reach for the horizontal rail.  The rail is good enough to cut if you need to.  Continue up on a few small crimps to an easier topout.

name: The Hourglass
description: Stem and/or pull inside of a huge hourglass shaped hueco to the lip, then make a tricky mantel over the top.

name: Uncut Yogi
description: Make moves up pitches and the arete until you can move right to a pocket and up on crimps. The start hold on this problem is getting very greasy and presents a real problem when you are standing on it as your feet need to stay to hold the terribly sloping hands.

name: The Maiden
description: Amazing rock and features combined with a low crux make this a must do highball. In many areas this would be a 3-5 bolt sport climb.    Move up the short wall to the roof and reach over. use a heal to turn the lip, this in itself is getting to be kind of high. Now cruise up the 25 foot tall gorgeous wall of big huecos.

name: Beer, Pizza and a 3 Foot Toothless Girl
description: Great diversity on a boulder problem. Great problem but can be painful, tape might help for the start.    Start out with a steep hands to cups crack. Then motor across the horizontal roof with some long reaches on pretty good holds. Finally fight through the bulge at the top on positive crimps.    Each section might be about V4 but by the time you get to the end you are spent.

name: Sledgehammer
description: Very unique and entertaining movement on an overhanging arete. If you enjoy pinches, heel hooks, compression, and flexing biceps, this climb hits the nail on the head.    Start sitting, hugging the arete with a good right hand pinch and a pretty poor left hand pinch on the face. Make a lefthand move up to a slopey hueco and work into the opposing sidepull crimps. Clever technique should lead you to the marquee move maneuvering through the large, made to order, sledgehammer pinch. From here, span out left to a deep jug, and exit onto the slab.

name: Chutes and Ladders
description: Stellar looking line that improbably makes a reasonable boulder problem. Multiple place you could start, the lowest of which would involve a series of long pulls on positive edges while exposing yourself to a poor landing with evidence that some of those edges have crumbled.     However, if you start from the middle landing area from a high right edge and a seam the rock is very good and there are only really 2 moves that feel exposed. From the crimp work your way up the seam until you can reach out right to an edge in a horizontal, then punch up to a buggy rail. Move up past another rail and jugs at the top.

name: El Fin
description: Start matched on a good left facing J-shaped jug. Make a few tricky moves out and slightly left to gain the lip. Continue left on holds at the lip until you gain a massive left hand jug and roll over the top. You could probably top out straight out from the start, but it looks extremely chossy.

name: Silverback
description: Start with a good left and a bad right undercling. Make moves on crimps and set up for either a large throw, or some more crimps to gain a good jug. Another large move gains you the jug just below the lip and a fairly casual top out.

name: Funk's Arete
description: Baffling that this is just now being added to MP. Sit-start with two hands on right side of arete, move left and up. One of the best for the grade in the park, no doubt.

name: 3 Star Arete
description: Stand start for 3 Star Arete Sit. Start with the left hand flake then head right and up along the right side pull to a jug rail at the top. Topout then downclimb around the chimney in the back made by a slick boulder.

name: 3 Star Arete Sit
description: Starts on two low slopers and moves up through some crimps and into the vertical seam, carefully avoiding the baby cactus growing out of the rock. Crank up and into the large left hand jug that starts the V2 variation. Beware of loose rock at the top.

name: Babia Majora
description: Thoughtful beta-intensive lower section.

name: The Real Bruce Lee
description: Looks intimidating, especially with no chalk on the holds, but a V0 nonetheless with excellent movement for the grade on bullet ironrock. Pretty bad landing but could be made pretty safe with 5+ pads.

name: Mystery Knobbler
description: Cute little boulder that packs a punch and has a surprising variety of movement. Sit-start with LH on good crimp and RH on low RH.

name: Best of the Best
description: One of the nicest problems in all of Hueco, long problem with a wide variety of interesting moves

name: Best of the West
description: Best of the West climbs a beautiful squeeze feature at the top of west mountain, directly behind the scepter.   start on low pockets, a couple of throws, slap moves ,and slopers lead to a fun mantle into a hueco off the the left.   some of the most classic moves and features hueco has to offer in the most ideal of settings.

name: Chewbacca
description: Chewbacca climbs the middle of the iron stone on the north face of The Scepter, about 30 feet to climber's right of the eponymous crack line. The business is in the first 25/30 feet, and I'm not really sure how to rate it. As a boulder problem, sheer terror might add a V grade or two, so it could be as "easy" as V7 or as hard as V10.    I did Chewbacca as a ground-up boulder problem, over two days, with crashpads and spotters. At one point, I climbed the easier (V3) corner to the right as a boulder/solo, to look at the lip holds and suss the top on Chewbacca, but that was the only pre-inspection.    The upper slab on both problems seemed to be 5.9/10 and went for another 20 or 30 feet, so don't fall up there. The wall is not radically overhanging, so I'm sure a good toprope could be arranged.

name: Echo Chamber
description: The full package. Filled with crimps, slopers, jugs; bicycles, heel/toe hooks, knee bars; small moves, big moves, in-between moves. A must-visit if you can find a guide who knows where it is. Seems to have settled at V8, but it's a fun problem to work even if it's a little above your pay-grade, as it is broken up into sections and you can pull on from various points.

name: Slovenian Classic
description: One of the most alluring jughauls to a committing and somewhat blind lip encounter. Start by reaching for bottom hueco lip and campusing to the next. Loses a star for all the choss.  Beware: Once you pull onto this thing, it WILL be difficult to reverse and step back down (you'll understand when you look at the landing). You must have good head game for this one. Also, as mentioned, it's chossy up top!

name: Shroom
description: Start with a left back step and move up and slightly across with your left to a very shallow, sharp edge. Step yoru right foot out onto a good point and rock up into an OK hueco undercling along a flared groove. Work your feet up and make a long pull to a sinker left handed sidepull pocket. Another long pull up to a pretty good edge with your right and bring your left foot up to a sloping edge near your hand level and pull over left to a good hold and an easier top out.    Pretty much pure power pulling, no real trickery, either you can hold the holds and pull off of them or you can't.

name: Animal Acts
description: Referred to as the slashface of V5.  Start sitting in an obvious hueco on good holds and move up and right to small crimps on the rail.  Make a few moderate moves on the rail to a big reach right and a hard match.  Reset and hit a good hueco then a huge jug.  From here walk up the easy finish.  Originally this problem was finished by avoiding the finishing jugs and using small crimps to the left.  This variation bumps the difficulty up to V6.

name: Animal Acts OG Exit
description: Start sitting in an obvious hueco on good holds and move up and right to small crimps on the rail. Make a few moderate moves on the rail to a big reach right and a hard match. Reset and hit a good hueco. Originally this problem was finished by avoiding the finishing jugs and using small crimps to the left. This variation bumps the difficulty up to V6.

name: Scream
description: Nice setting and just a sick power boulder with the coolest ice "scream" scooped pockets. The traditional version (v11) starts on the lower set of sprag-pockets around head/chest height. There are two other recognized starts: the high stand version (V10) starts on the higher set of better pockets, and the sit-start, called Ice Cream (v12), starts on the ledge down low.

name: Splash it on and be Selfless
description: Start directly below the obvious black water groove on a right facing hueco. Navigate through the short roof and continue upwards towards the airy summit. Stay attentive on the somewhat solid, lichen-covered holds as you near the top - a fall from up high would be disastrous.    Note - At opportune times throughout the year the Wellsite is filled with water, completely covering the fallzone in ankle-deep ponding water. For the bold, this marks the moment to either send or splash.

name: Clawfoot
description: Start matched in good juggy huecos.  Make a long reach to the left for a crimp. Match and continue left until you can go up and top out through jugs.

name: Rock'em Sock'em
description: Excellent quality highball about 20' to the right of Splash it On And Be Selfless.  Start standing on the skirt with small crimps (directly across from the base of the tree). Do a couple of moves on crimper plates then up the right side of the giant Hueco.  There's a good rest in the second Hueco at about 20'. Easier climbing on good incut crimps all the way to the top.

name: The Bathtub
description: A really good long and varied rising traverse. The landing follows the problem for much of it's length and you are not far off the ground until the very end which is a bit easier.    Start low and left from a sit and boulder up on some smaller crimpy holds, there is one that is pretty bad. Eventually you move up and right into slopers along the bottom of the "bathtub" feature. Work across the slopers to the other end of the "bathtub". Move up into the right end of the "bathtub" and out on underclings and pinches to a big move up to a jug. At this point you are starting to get up off the ground a bit. Move up the face with long moves between pretty good holds.

name: Eckagrata
description: Eckagrata is essentially two moves of V6 do a hard dyno to a V2/4 top out depending on if you choose to go straight up at the top out or traverse to the left on jugs.  The PG-13 rating is for the latter top out as you climb over a boulder that would hurt to land on.  This problem is also known as the Wellsite Dyno.

name: Star Power
description: One of the best V5s at Hueco.  Don't be deceived by starting at the constriction between the floor and roof - look down into the dark depths for the real start.  This climbs over 30 ft and you can step off at almost any point!   Start all the way at the back moving a bit left then back right into the ass-dragger constriction and a rest.  Continue up the face with a heart-breaker pinch near the end.

name: Crash Dummy
description: This line gets credit for being the only 4 star V7 in Hueco according to the Wilder guide.  I'm not sure if it's the best, but it is certainly classic and up their with BabyFace and Roughage.  Start laying down up on a shelf with a heel / toe cam and hands on a left facing shelf.  Climb leftwards thru a good pocket and a big reach left with a kneescum.  Figure out how to get the good pinch hold without dabbing on the rock behind.  Climb up through the series of cool pockets and pinches to a fun but still engaging topout.

name: Death by Mambo
description: Start on the left side of the wall with a jug undercling. Traverse right on good holds making a shouldery crux in the middle of the roof. Good footwork and jugs lead to a thin, but easy mantle.

name: Between the Cheeks
description: Same start as Sheets. Pull the first couple of moves, then veer off right into a rad sequence that gets you into the crimps and undercling jug.  Like Sheets, this climb is awfully dabby, but has excellent movement.

name: Natural Disaster
description: Start standing in the back of the roof, and work your way to the layback feature and final jump to the jug. As good as any 10 out there.

name: Long Dong Roof
description: If The Wheel of life were half as long and 2/3rd's easier AND at Hueco Tanks you'd have a climb like Long Dong Roof. Super fun. A really cool feature to climb on.

name: Bobby Donuts
description: Start on a right facing right hand sloper-edge and matched left just above. Do a few move straight up and slightly right then continue trending left making sure not to bash your dome on the adjacent rock.

name: Bobby Boston Cream
description: Although it might seem obvious to start on the huge left facing jug, it actually starts on two sloping jugs just to the left. Make some moves right off the jug into a bad left hand pinch. Find a way to grab the good in-cut right hand crimp and top out as for Bobby's Doughnut.

name: Planet Zeist
description: Bullet proof 45 degree overhang starting matched in undercling and climbing out left and up for top out.

name: The Devil's Butthole
description: This one of a kind rock climb, although in a less traveled area, is a must see problem in the Hueco Tanks backcountry when the usual locations are starting to get a bit bland and monotonous.    Starts with a large tongue at the bottom exit. Squeeze your way out 36 feet of roof climbing with the landing never being more than 5 feet behind you. Halfway through you will encounter the infamous Devil's Butthole, a dark, vast hole that easily fits six grown men inside of it (possibly more?). Venture in as far as you dare, but according to Verm, "flashlights are off route."    At the butthole you have two options - either crawl in for a rest, a game of cards, or possibly a cup of coffee, or, bypass the butthole and grit your way around the rim, continuing upwards leaving the darkness behind. Work your way towards the light and finish on the slab above.    With a little bit of everything, from jugs to pinches and kneebars to heel hooks this one is guaranteed to not leave a bad taste in your mouth.

name: Booty Slapper
description: Start on Bodysnatcher and go left to the lip.

name: Warm-up Slab
description: Excellent warm-up area if you're going to be in this area or just don't want to go to The Maze. Bc I'm lazy I'm just putting them under one climb. There are 5 climbs or so on this face, but 3 stand out. 1) Cookie Butter V0- (start left of the shallow hueco dish in big rock scar) 2) Nookie Butter V0 (start with the shallow hueco dish) 3) Bushman V0 (to the right of the above two climbs; start low on nice crimps and go up very nice scar features)

name: Round Room Traverse
description: Simple! Traverse around the room either clockwise or counterclockwise. See how many laps you can do without stepping off!  For a really challenge try and do it in under 1-minute. The record is supposedly around 30-sec

name: Corey The Pimp
description: A long roof traverse capped with a cruxy start and finish. Start in two underclings below obvious left hand edge and right hand slope, and venture through a sea of jugs to the heartbreaker finish into the toilet bowl. You could also extend into the Lead Belly finish, making it probably around V8.  The real Mark of the Beast: this line, Long Dong, and Devil's Butthole.

name: Inside Out
description: Line sends an arete that is located inside the North End Group maze. Standing start heads up to to two pockets and a jug top out. Avoid using your back on the boulder behind. Could be a bit height dependent for the start but is a fine line.

name: Welcome to the Dark Side
description: Standing start avoiding the right edge and avoiding using the boulder to the left. The chimney problem is a separate route. The arete edge to the right is a separate route.

name: Easy on Backside of Burma
description: Easy.

name: Classic Warm Up
description: The crux is at the top.

name: Second Degree
description: Murder Slab variation. Using the right arete at the bottom, climb your way up and into Murder Slab.

name: Murder Slab
description: Crux is pulling up to the slab.

name: Baby Crane
description: Sit start left hand low in crack, right around the arete. Gain left arete and do a couple cool moves to a chill topout. Definitely fun!

name: No Foot Left Behind
description: Start just to the left of Shaking hands with God.  Climb completely under the roof using the jam crack.  Interesting and unique movement will see you out of the crack (don't lose your foot in the process). Exit up and to the right.

name: Hard Arete
description: Hard face.

name: Purple Gold
description: Start from a stand with your left hand on the arete and right on an undercling that will pinch you if not grabbed just right.  Pull on and climb up through the center of the wall through edges, a sidepull and big moves.  An easy mantle gets you on top.  A real gem I think, and surely one of the best of the grade in park.  Wait for a dry day, this thing can be wet sometimes.

name: Mad Cow
description: This is an intimidating, awesome line I forgot to add a while back.  From a stand on the ledge, climb the thin vertical face right of hard arête.  A good one to have many pads at your disposal.

name: Twinkle Toes
description: Start right of Pinball Arete in the horizontal seam, with your right hand in a pod hold and left on a slimper next to it.  Climb leftwards through a technical and powerful sequence and finish up Pinball Arete.

name: Face Time
description: Good one. Climbs ledges with some crimps added in.

name: Elephant Ear
description: The guidebook says 5.11a, but it's only 25 feet and has a good landing.

name: Left of Elephant Ear
description: Side pulls up the face to an interesting top out.

name: Arrested Layback
description: Climb the sharp flake. Guidebook say 5.7 but it's very protectable with pads. Classic.

name: Committee Climbing
description: Climb steep face to nice layback up high.  Super fun climb.  Given 5.10b in the new guide.

name: Stankonia
description: Great route. The landing looks bad but isn't because the only place to pop will send you on a casual fall on top of a flat boulder.

name: Fudge Shoppe
description: Fun

name: Jack Backwards
description: In the 3rd edition guidebook. Listed as project.    April 2016   Pull off the ground and move though good holds to bomber ledge.  Chalk up and reach back in the dihedral for a less then good edge, set your feet and make a committing reach left.  High-step on the ledge, press into the dihedral then continue to good holds for the finish.

name: Big Money Project
description: SDS near left side of cave.  Right hand on good edge and left hand-heel match out left.  Cross through to small crack and bump out right to a shitty two finger pocket and throw to the finish- hard!  Small and sharp holds through the crux.  Surprisingly this is not a dabby problem.  Super cool!

name: Vanishing Point
description: Sit start on the left facing jug and climb up interesting holds that are strangely worse than they appear.

name: Vision Quest
description: Start underneath the obvious tall arete with a giant foot.  A few steep moves lead you into squeeze moves on the face.  An airy, easing and slightly insecure finish awaits.  A real beauty.

name: Fever Dream
description: From an edge and a sidepull just next to it, climb the face not using the crack or sidepull features right.  Very subtle movement on this one and not a give away.  The crux comes at the lip and pulling the bulge.

name: Dream Fatigue
description: Start on the large jug. Climb great holds up the compression feature to a tricky topout.

name: The Ejaculator
description: The Ejaculator problem is a classic.  SDS with good holds and work your way up the breaks in rock.  Steep powerful moves from under the boulder lead to slapping your way out to the corner.  A must do for the DL boulderer

name: Pussy Whipped
description: Climb up short, steep, and extremely powerful crack in rock.  Properly named due to the fact that Eric's wife kept calling him during his send efforts.

name: Buzz Bomb
description: No text - use the 'Improve This Page' link to add something useful!

name: Jones' Roof?
description: Sweet hidden overhang problem. Start on good underclings and make big moves straight over the roof. Things get brutal at the lip!

name: Agape
description: Climb face left of the arete on the Titan boulder, capped by a triangular prow & press it out. Enjoy the ride if you miss the huck!

name: The Titan (aka Birthday Prow)
description: This gem is waiting for an ascent. When first glancing at it it looks simple, that is until you try crankin' on it. Big features with even bigger moves. Git on it!

name: Slice of Life
description: Although squat in stature when compared to the classic routes next to it, this interesting feature has quality rock and is worth climbing. Start sitting with hands low on the face and a heel out left in the dish. Hike your weight, throw for the ledge and try to stick a solid V4 crux move. From here move up to some good holds, step up into the crack and top out to the right. The friction in the horizontal is superb, you may actually lose some skin trying this one!

name: Amazing pillar original route
description: THE classic with the arete on the pillar. Climb up center of tall face with slab below(don't worry you'll easily clear it if you blow it)and follw crimps and rails to the top. Inspect the top out for accumulated debris first as the top out is super good if clean and scary if dirty.

name: Amazing Pillar
description: On SE corner of pillar: start with left hand on large pinch, work your feet up and get small crimp on face, get your left hand up, hike feet and throw for good hold up and left.  A classic DL hard problem!  Easier for the tall in my opinion.

name: Amazing Face
description: Start on the face left of Amazing Pillar and climb the left side of the Amazing Pillar.  The crux is up high, make sure to have a few pads and spotters as a fall will probably put you right on a rock in the landing. I believe this is right of the Original Route but correct me if I'm wrong.

name: The Magician
description: Climb up the pretty arete from the obvious jug start.

name: Welcome Crack
description: Climb up tall and super fun crack.

name: Tall Boy
description: Climb up features in steep and tall face.  Super fun and a great warm up.

name: Its Bumpin
description: This is the direct line up the arete of the warm up wall. Start sitting with feet together low on the arete and with arms fully outstretched. From a sharp good undercling left and an incut side pull right, make a series of bumps up to a stand.  From here a fun campus move can be done to reset feet with style. Stay on the arete to top out

name: Roll Top
description: Begin with stacked fists. Chicken wing up into a heinous foot jam, flex your knee and reach up for a solid fist. Pull up to an insecure and exposed mantle and roll your way to safety for the top out.

name: Flying Mancuso
description: Start with good ledge, slap right hand up and undercling with left, fight your way to the top.

name: SW Corner of Lake Boulder
description: Start low and climb up slopeing arete.  Lake boulder classic.

name: lake boulder lunge
description: On the left side of the east face of the lake boulder is the classic huck of the reserve. climb into two good sidepulls and shoot for a perfect soap dish and top out on the center of the face. EZ and I were repeatidly missing the hold while being heckeled by a buch of drunks and pot heads before it got sent.

name: Insidious
description: This is in the el parasol roof.  The start is pictured, link into Midwest Dream.  The big move on Midwest Dream is a bit heady, do be careful.

name: face left of west face lake boulder
description: Instead of climbing the standard route up the west face climb the face to the left using a smeared palm and decent side pull with th eright hand. A tenuous move out left to a camo'd crimp leads to good pulls to the top and a straight mantle finish. One of my favorites at the reserve.

name: Struggle Bus
description: Start with feet outside the crack and step into a bad knee jam. Wrestle your way up to a good ledge and pull into a good rest. Press up into another knee and mantle out of the widening.

name: The Bottle
description: Start with hands on both sides of pillar. Move your feet up and work your way up the left arete, using good compression and small feet to keep yourself on. Go straight up for the slopey top out, make sure it is clean first.    Bonus points for sit start.

name: Power of the Scoop
description: Using cracks, hike your way up side-pulls and move out to slopey arete to jug.  From there work your way up slopers to top.  Tricky.

name: Starfish
description: On the east face of the Lake Boulder, start with left hand on small edge and move up to starfish like hold, hike your feet up and throw for the doughy lip up right.  Top out straight up.  Classic!

name: Corner right of Starfish
description: This is one of my favorites.  Climb corner just right of Starfish.  Start with left hand on icey side pull, paste feet and throw for good sloper.  Match hand and heel and yard up to the slopey lip.

name: Le Eagle
description: From a sit, left hand with a sloper and right with a sidepull, gain slopers and mantle into the scoop.  Pretty much a sit start to the problem Spread Eagle.

name: Ursa Major
description: This is a bear-y good lip traverse on the back side of the boulder below the Lake boulder.  Start with your left hand on a triangular notch, and right hand in an oblong pocket.  Slap and shuffle to the right along the lip until you gain better holds around the corner, and can top out where Short Boulder finishes.

name: Tall Boy Sit
description: Sit start the mega classic Tall Boy with a crimp for the left and a low undercling for the right.  Some folks feel that starting matched on the left crimp makes it even better.

name: The Gasch Traverse
description: On the south face of the lake boulder, start with your left hand on an undercling on/close to the SW arete, and your right on the sloper rail right.  Pull on and move right through the slopes and top out on the SE arete.  Fun and powerful moves, and if you like slopers you will like this.

name: The Powerful Mancuso
description: Start matched in the constriction of horizontal crack 5' left of Flying Mancuso, make a large left hand move and then go right to the sloper.

name: Man of War
description: A trafficked problem that is well liked. Sit start with underclings.  Grab the small, sharp crimp and climb the blunt arete.

name: Asteroidea
description: An obvious, natural sit to Starfish.  Start seated on the left side of the face beneath "Lake Boulder Lunge" with your left hand on an undercling and right hand on a gritty edge.  Climb through the crack up and right into Starfish.  Stick the jump and top out as on that problem.

name: Caught Off Guard
description: Climb the obvious crack.

name: Surprise The Moss
description: Sit start just left of the crack and go straight up to the wide ledge to a somewhat tricky topout.

name: Surprise Party
description: Starts on a large, obvious jug and goes up and right on the face.  I ran out of light to get on this but it looks like the best line on the boulder.

name: Surprise Arête
description: Climb up the arête just to the right of the dihedral used in Ruining the Surprise.

name: Pleasant Surprise
description: Original problem starts on two side pulls below the slab and goes directly up and over the cool slab.  Can also be started as for Out Of The Blue and traverse right to the slab.    Excellent problem with a really cool move over the slab!

name: Out Of The Blue
description: Sit start the same as for Backside Surprise Right, but after two moves trend left onto the face.  Follow a crack system to a good hold and an incredible pinch with an easy topout.  Fantastic problem!

name: Sneak Attack
description: Starts on a low jug that looks detached but isn't really and goes straight up to the obvious jug and then follows the crack directly left on small holds.  Tops out in the crack.

name: Pot Mouth
description: Start on opposing holds in the middle of the face and climb up on great, comfy holds to a fun topout.  Fantastic warmup.

name: Methier Mouth
description: Start low on the face, just left of Mouthin' Off and climb up and into Meth Mouth.  Adds a handful of moves into Meth Mouth.

name: Logical Bastard
description: Fun mantle problem 2 minutes from the parking lot.

name: Dorothy's Slab
description: A very nice slab climb up the tallest face of the prominent pillar in the Shark Tooth area. Starts on the bulge above the horizontal break, and follows a ledge system up and left across the face.  Named in honor of my grandmother Dorothy who recently passed away.

name: Scent of Blood
description: Start with right hand on jug underneath the roof and left hand on slopey edge. A few powerful moves lead up the arete.

name: Shark Tooth
description: From an obvious sit, left hand on the arete and right on a slanting, glassy sidepull, climb the arete trending slightly right to finish.  A sustained and very good problem.

name: Secrets Of The Lake Project
description: Start on a low edge/undercling and go up the face trending right.  Couple of obvious crimps on the face.

name: There is no White Knight
description: There is no White Knight is a sit start from a positive crimp rail. After two really hard crimp moves, you move to the triangle ledge and up the fun topout. This is a very fun dihedral, despite being a short problem. The topout features engaging moves on comfy holds.

name: Sail Away
description: Hard start.  Stand start with high right hand on arete and left down on pinch.  Get your feet established and crank up and out overhang of boulder. The upper moves are fantastic!   There is a jump start that skips the first hard move.  V4/5

name: Krishna
description: Start left hand on lower sidepull crimp and right hand around the arete higher on a good sidepull. Make a move into a larger sidepull then hold tension to work through the lip and slopers on the face of the boulder. A short but sweet boulder that requires you maintain tension throughout.

name: There are Two
description: The sit start to "There's No White Knight."  Start seated with a juggy right hand pinch under the roof and your left hand on a thin edge.

name: Green Haze
description: Direct start to Green Fire.    SDS with left hand on blocky gaston on arete and right hand on good edge, and move up to side-pull.  Set feet and toss up to crimp on Green Fire.  Top-out.

name: Full Sail
description: Sit start with your right hand on a good, sharp crimp just left of the arete and your left hand on a lower edge. Climb into "Sail Away."

name: Midwest Connection
description: This is the large slab that is at the north-west end of the talus field. We climbed the cleaner looking slab face on the left, but there is the possibility to finish out right. The rock quality is very questionable though on the right side, and most likely should be avoided.

name: Galapagos
description: Stand start with left hand jug-edge and right hand crimp edge. Work your way out to the jug on the face then top out.

name: All Along The Messenger Shore
description: Start on obvious jugs in the crack and go straight up to a small series of crimps.  Top out around the nose of the boulder.

name: The Glass Bench
description: Head up the low angle slab to the base of the hanging block. Use both aretes to gain a very committing smear foot. A few more bumps, bad feet, and a toehook leads to a victory jug and a cruiser finish.

name: Over the Garden Wall
description: Sit start on the white crimp and a lower slopey edge. Continue directly up the face using a series of faint crimps, while avoiding crack to the left.

name: Cloven Hoof
description: Start on a large jug feature below the roof. Work through a series of slopers and non-holds to the lip.

name: Baphomet (Project)
description: An extremely obvious and difficult line that exits a ~45 degree overhang. Sit start on low jug rail. A series of left hand crimps and right hand sloper/compression features leads to a huge throw to a full pad edge. Topout using another set of decent slopers.

name: Massive Vertigo
description: Start on the crimp rail towards the bottom of the pit and climb up and left to the sloper on the arete.  Go up from here.    Ed:  Originally given V8, new/easier beta has been found (see below-- sweaty's video is him doing the original V8).

name: Remo's Sacrifice
description: Super proud!  Stand start with steep arete and gain sloper.  Toss out right to good hold and hike up to small crimps above the lip.  Finish move is super committing.   A sit start should be added for full value and added difficulty, but the holds were too wet for us to try.

name: Tunder Tighs
description: Start left hand on good edge and right hand on pinch rail. Using some tensiony heel hooks and compression, make huge moves up to the lip then up and over.

name: Puke, Master-flash
description: Start left hand on good ledge and jump for right hand edge.  Get your feet on and move up boulder with a big cross-over move to a jug.  Powerful moves and props to Aaron for this contribution.    Starting lower with both hand below is still an awesome open project.

name: Fontesque
description: Start underneath the arete with left hand on a toothlike hold and right on a pinch undercling.  Climb the arete with balance, gain the obvious holds on the face and top out.  This is also on here as the impossiproject.

name: Nausea
description: Start the same as "Tunder Tighs" and climb directly up the face with a small pit underneath you..  Formerly the "Big Boy Project"

name: Fearful Symmetry
description: Formerly the "Crack of Doom" project.  Begin with your left hand in the crack and right hand on a jug sidepull.  Make an easy move before diving into five moves of powerful yet technical climbing.  A committing layback move guards the lip.  Proud!

name: Elbow Room
description: Start with right hand in slot and left on crimp.  Set left foot and gun for pocket.  A couple more big moves get you to a heady top-out.  Fun!

name: High Room
description: Same start as High-Low.  At good edge, bump out to pocket and finish up on Elbow Room.  Fun link-up!

name: The Warbler
description: Start under roof with right hand jug and left had pinch.  Set feet and make a big move to a good edge.  Move right through pinches and slopers to top-out.   Really fun movement!

name: Manta Ray
description: A pure line, definitely cool, and very unique.  Start hanging from the edge near the arete and surmount the hanging block feature. Hint: We campused left for the first move and threw a heal hook..

name: Whetstone
description: Stand start on the obvious sloper rail. Climb up the steep wall to a crux topout.

name: North by Northwest
description: From a stand with a ledge, climb the tall arete.  Pads and spotters recommended.  Tall and committing near the top.

name: Sir Mix Alot
description: Starting right hand on jug and left hand on a cool pinch old on the arete, climb out the steep arete doing some awesome and fun moves then do an interesting topout above the boulder.

name: Smooth Operator
description: Stand start with good side-pulls and work your way up left to slopey arete, finish the slick top-out.  Super cool.

name: Bud White
description: Sit down start of Smooth Operator.    Start on slopey ledge down and right of the start to SO.  Bump out left to crack and get into the start of SO.  Top out same as SO

name: Tilted Boulder Project
description: Climb up corner of leaning boulder.  There may be a project on the face to the left too.

name: What Up Weasel
description: Start sitting underneath the steep prow with your left hand on the arete and your right on a smallish, but good edge.  Hard move to the jug, some compression moves and trickery, and go up the face on good edges and slopers.  A weasel skittered right by us as we were working the problem.

name: Tilted Sloper Project
description: From the left, trend right along the lip through cool and bad holds and finish up the right arete.

name: Tilted Face Project
description: Pull on to the face, with a bitey right side pull left of the arete for the right hand, and an undercling for the left.  Establish, probably fire to a sloper on the lip then move right to the arete and finish it up.

name: Fairy Tale
description: Start sitting with a right sidepull and faint left sidepull.  A crux first move leads to fun and easier climbing to the apex of the arête.

name: Awesome Blossom
description: Start from a sit with a right crimp and a thin left sidepull.  Gain a slopey hold for the left hand, bust big right to an incut hold and finish it up.

name: Good Touch
description: Getting started is the hard park. Get your right hand on the best part of the lip and heel hook with your right. Move out to a awesome hold on the face and follow the lip to the top. Fun stuff!

name: Big Red
description: From the right on a pedestal climb up the beautiful slab.  Amazing and exposed climbing over a terrible landing.  The crux is at the top.  Could be easier but don't want to sandbag this one.  I checked it out on a rope first.

name: Shoo Fly
description: Sit start on a crimp and jug on the lip with a heel hook.  Work your way up the arete on nice slopers/sloper jugs and top out.  Face still requires some heavy cleaning.

name: The Great Eye
description: A great slab problem. Few holds on a near perfect slab. This ride might have a height requirement! Awesome slot hold near the top that looks like a eye!!

name: The Walrus
description: From a sit on the left side of the downhill face, with your left hand on an edge on the left side of the arete, and your right on a block pinch, trend right, staying low through edges.  Gain a crack and wrap around the corner.. and keep wrapping until you hit the north arete and top out.  Long and pumpy, and it would be tough or scary to top out earlier.

name: Stanage Arete
description: Pretty fun hanging arete problem with some dynamic moves and a fun top out.
